What is PandaGarage?
Where can I get this board?
How can I support this project?
The external API can be used to control the garage door by other systems or software.
PandaGarage has two APIs. The internal and the external API.
To facilitate troubleshooting, you can select the log level you want to log in the Device Settings. Default is set to none.

On this page, you can configure various settings for your device.
PandaGarage supports Home Assistant over MQTT.
As the WebUI is password protected for security reasons, you can change this password on this page.

Currently the following languages are supported:
PandaGarage Docs

The external API can be used to control the garage door by other systems or software. tip If authentication is enabled, you need to provide a Authorization header with a token. More details are below. Successful calls will return status code 200 or 201. Other status codes that can return are: 400 - Bad Request This indicates, that the requested endpoint is not found. 401 - Unauthorized This indicates, that either the Authorization header or the X-Access-Source header is missing or wrong. Currently the X-Access-Source is only required for the control endpoint. 403 - Forbidden This indicates, that the requested endpoint is not reachable.

post /api/auth üîì Send a POST request to the endpoint with Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded and include pwd=<your password> in the request body. The response will return an authentication token ‚Äî add it as the Authorization header on all subsequent protected requests. { "token": "68asc...s18" }

get /api/info üîì Returns informations about the board if the API is up and running. { "mac": "08:A6:F7:A8:6B:14", "ip": "192.168.1.92", "hostname": "PandaGarage-6B", "rssi": -54, "version_fw": "0.1.57", "version_fs": "0.1.20", "version_hw": "1.0", "sn": "pg_52gjw_0000", "uptime": 418069 } get /api/status üîì Call this endpoint to get the current status of the garage door and it's sensors. Response will be: { "status": "ok", "version_fw": "0.1.55", "door": { "position_current": 0, "position_target": 0, "state": "closed", "moving": false, "light": false }, "sensor": { "temperature": 33.35571, "humidity": 35.55908, "lux": 237, "externalSensor": "none" } } post /api/restart üîì Call this endpoint to restart your PandaGarage. Response will be: { "status": "restarting" }

post /api/control üîí The control endpoint is used to control the actual garage door. If the request was successful, the response will be a simple JSON message: { "status": "ok" } You need to provide an action parameter, containing one of the following values: open to open the garage door close to close the garage door stop to stop the garage door movement vent to move the garage door into vent position half to move the garage door into half position position move the garage door to a specific position. An additional position parameter is required. the value can be between 0 and 100 light to control the built in light. An additional optional state parameter can be set with the values on or off. if no additional parameter is provided, the light will simply be toggled Additionally to the Authorization header, the control endpoint requires a X-Access-Source header. This header must be set to api, otherwise you will receive a 401 error. When the request has a wrong parameter or is missing a parameter the response will be: { "status": "invalid" } post /api/buzzer/play üîí Call this endpoint to play a provided tune from the buzzer. You need to provde a tune parameter, with the value of the tune you want to play. Currently 1-4. Response will be: { "status": "ok" }
PandaGarage has two APIs. The internal and the external API. Both APIs are secured by the WebUI password (if authentification is enabled).

The internal API is currently not documented, as it is meant to be used by the WebUI for setup and settings. Please don't use this one for custom requests, because it could change very often with each update.
The external API could be used to build custom requests or to integrate it with other systems / software. It's endpoints are documented on the external API page.

To facilitate troubleshooting, you can select the log level you want to log in the Device Settings. Default is set to none. Debug logs almost anything happening while error or warning log only when an error occurs or when something needs your attention. All logs are saved into a csv file.

Navigate to the "Log" page in the WebUI. View the log entries directly on the page. Use the available options to either: Delete the log file. Download the log file for further analysis. Enabling logging at debug level is a helpful way to identify issues and understand what is happening within the system.

PandaGarage gives you the option to export a so called diagnostics zip file. This file includes all available logs and all your settings. This can be used to troubleshoot your settings or logs (for example if your PandaGarage is disconnecting from the garage door motor). To download the diagnostics ZIP, go to Settings > Device and, in the Logging section, click the ‚ÄúDownload Diagnostics‚Äù button.
This guide will help you to assemble your PandaGarage board and power it up.

You can either use the official PandaGarage case from MakerWorld or design your own based on the original model. All found here. The mounting holes on the PCB are made for M3 screws, in case you want to mount the PCB somewhere.

Your PandaGarge will be powered by the garage door motor. So you don't need any external power supply. When connected to a PC, the power supply by a USB-C port will be enough. USB-C for PC connection RJ12 Connector for garage door connection danger Only use one power supply option at a time. Otherwise, you may damage your board. Also, flashing is only possible using the USB-C power option, or using the UART header and powering the 3.3V pin. The RJ12 powering is only possible when connected to the garage door motor.
Power Source Current (A) Voltage (V) RJ12 1 24 USB 1 5

This guide will help you set up your PandaGarage board. When you buy the board, it comes pre flashed with the latest firmware. There are two methods to set up your device: Using the web installer Building and flashing the firmware locally tip The driver installation is optional, because the host os should install the driver automatically.
Connect your PandaGarage to your PC using a USB-C cable. Open the Web Installer. Follow the on-screen instructions.

When you want to flash the firmware locally, you can either use the USB-C connection or use the UART Header with an external flasher. To build and flash the firmware locally, follow these steps: Download or clone the repository. Open the project using PlatformIO and VS Code. Connect your PandaGarage to your PC using a USB-C cable, or an external flasher. Build and upload the filesystem image. Build and upload the firmware.
Here you can find different parts and where you can buy them.
Official PandaGarage Case can be found on MakerWorld. MakerWorld

The firmware currently supports the following external sensors out of the box: AHT10 Temperatur & Humidity Sensor SCD40 CO2 Sensor SCD41 CO2 Sensor CCS811 CO2 Sensor VL6180X Distaance Sensor These links may be affiliate links that support this project.
Open your smartphone and connect to the PandaGarage WiFi network. Once connected, there will open a webpage, which looks like the screenshot below. Press the Let's go button.

This page will give you the option to change the name of your PandaGarage. This name will be used to identify your device on your network and for Home Assistant. You can also select your preffered WebUI language here. This option can be changed later in the settings.

When you're on this page, the setup was done successfully. You will now see the connected network name, the device IP address and the default password to login into the WebUI. After you have noted the details, press "Restart now". The device will close the hotspot connection and will connect to your local network after restart. Now navigate to the shown ip address or access it using http://YOUR DEVICE NAME.local or if its the only PandaGarage on your network by entering http://pandagarage.local.

On this page you will connect your PandaGarage to your local network. Press the Scan network button to start scanning for networks. After the scan succeeds, select the network you want to connect to from the list. If your network is hidden, you can press the "Other Network" item, to configure your network on your own. After pressing your found network or "Other Network", the following screen will appear, where you can either enter your network details. When done, press "Save & Connect" to test the network details. If a connection could be established, you will see a corresponding message and press "Close" and see the final step, otherwise you need to reenter the network details.
The board features 2 header pins. One is labeled as UART, the second one is labeled as I2C.

The UART pins can be connected to an external flasher to flash the board, if for any reason the onboard flashing isn't working. Please reffer to the following image for the pin labeling: The pins from left to right are: EN IO0 3.3V RX TX Ground
The I2C pins can be used to connect additional I2C devices like other sensors. Please reffer to the following image for pin labeling: The pins from top to bottom are: GND 3.3V SCL SDA

After the initial setup was done, and you're able to access the WebUI on your local network, it's time to connect your PandaGarage to your garage door motor (if not done already). You will see that the status on the WebUI shows "not connected" below the garage door. That's because the garage door motor needs to perform a bus scan to actually find the new connected device. Depending on your garage door motor model, there are two ways to perform this scan: ProMatic Serie 4 Use the bottom dip switch, to start the bus scan. SupraMetic E/P Serie 4 Use the buttons on the front panel to navigate to menu 37 and start the bus scan (option 01). See this german tutorial. When the bus scan was successfully, you will see that the status changed on the Dashboard to the current garage door state (you may need to refresh the web page). On your Dashboard you can control the door with basic up, down and stop commands, turn the light on / off or use the position commands for venting and half opening the door. You will see a little animation on door movement and see a visual representation of door position. Below the door controls are the sensor readings of the onboard sensors, and if enabled, the external sensor readings. The sensor values are updated if their values change without a page refresh. Now you're ready to use your PandaGarage. Be sure to check the settings guide for more details on all the functions PandaGarage provides.

Here you'll find a collection of ready-to-use automation examples for your installation. These automations are designed specifically for Node-RED. Simply copy the provided code and replace the example entities with your own. tip If you've created an automation you'd like to share, please open an issue on GitHub ‚Äî I'll review it and consider adding it to the list.

This automation will move the garage door to vent position, if the temperature exceeds 35¬∞C for over 10 minutes. documents.s: Restart PandaGarage if connection is lost

documents.t: PandaGarage exposes the following entities in Home Assistant: Cover Light Buttons Sensors Update
This is the main entity for controlling your garage door. You can operate it using the Up, Down, and Stop commands, or by setting a specific door position.
This entity controls the garage door light. It only supports switching the light on or off.

The available buttons are: Half position ‚Äì Moves the door to the half-open position Vent position ‚Äì Opens the door to the ventilation position Toggle Door ‚Äì Opens or closes the door depending on its current state Restart ‚Äì Restarts the PandaGarage device These buttons are stateless and just support clicking it. They won't show if the door is e.g. in vent position or not.
The exposed sensors include: Temperature Humidity Pressure Lux (Light Intensity) If external sensors are configured, their corresponding values will also be displayed.
The update entity indicates whether a new firmware version is available. During an update, it displays the current progress and status of the installation.
Additionally, the firmware version, hardware version, and device serial number are provided in the device info card. Clicking the visit link will open the WebUI.

To integrate PandaGarage with your Home Assistant setup, you‚Äôll need an MQTT broker. The most popular choice is the Mosquitto MQTT broker. For installation instructions, see the Home Assistant MQTT integration guide here. Once your MQTT broker is installed, create a new set of credentials specifically for PandaGarage (alternatively, you can use your existing Home Assistant login credentials).

After entering and saving your MQTT credentials on the Home Assistant settings page in PandaGarage, your device should automatically appear in the MQTT integration within Home Assistant. When you open the PandaGarage device in Home Assistant, it should appear similar to this:

Each boards has a unique serial number printed on the board and the ESP chip. The serial number can be seen on the WebUI under the info page or by scanning the QR code printed on the back of the board. The serial number is used to validate that the board is authentic and to check production date, production batch and hardware revision. You can validate your serial number here: Check!Scan QR
On this page, you can configure various settings for your device. info Don't forget to save your changes!

Device Name: Change your device name. This name will be used for Home Assistant, network hostname and many other places to identify this device. If you are using multiple PandaGarage boards in the same network, make sure that each device has an unique name. WebUI Language: Select your preferred language for the WebUI.

Temperature: Select the unit for the temperature sensor. Update Interval: Specify how frequently the sensor is read, in milliseconds. Temperature Threshold: Configure the minimum temperature variation required to register as a change. Humidity Threshold: Configure the minimum humidity variation required to register as a change. Pressure Threshold: Configure the minimum pressure variation required to register as a change. Light Threshold: Configure the minimum lux variation required to register as a change.

Activation: Enable this option, if you have connected an external sensor to the I2C header. External Sensor: Select the external sensor you have connected. If you cannot find the connected sensor in the list, please open an issue on GitHub, so I can add the sensor to the list, or edit the code to add your own sensor. Combine Sensors: When enabling this option, sensor of the same type, like multiple temperature sensors, are combined and they're combined value is shown. A list of currently supported external sensor can be found here

Activation: Enable this option to use the onboard buzzer. Tune: Select which melody should be played. Play: Press this button to play the selected tune. Play on door opening: Activate this option, to play the selected tune on door opening. Play on door closing: Activate this option, to play the selected tune on door closing.

Access Logging: Enable this option to log each interaction with the garage door over PandaGarage. This will document on how the device was accessed and what was done. Log Level: Select the verbosity you want to log. If you don't want the logs, select none. Download Diagnostics: Downloads a diagnostics ZIP file. Details: Refer to the Debugging Guide for more information
Function: Resets the device to factory settings. danger This will delete all changes made by you.

PandaGarage supports Home Assistant over MQTT. The following is exposed to MQTT: Device information like device name, firmware version, settings page link Garage door controls and status Built in sensors Depending on device configuration: External sensors Reboot button

First you need to enable and configure the Home Assistant connection. You need the IP address and port of your MQTT broker and the username / password. It's recommended to create a new MQTT user for PandaGarage.

PandaGarage exposes it self using discovery functionality, therefore your PandaGarage will be automatically discovered by Home Assistant and added to your setup. If you don't see it, try restarting your Home Assistant. You can use this functionality, to implement your own automations without using the PandaGarage WebUI or to just monitor your PandaGarage sensors and status. The integration is build to support multiple PandaGarages in your network.
You can also use the MQTT integration to also control / monitor your PandaGarage without Home Assistant if you want. Just be sure to communicate the same way Home Assistant would.
As the WebUI is password protected for security reasons, you can change this password on this page. The passwords needs to be at least 4 charachters long.

You can disable WebUI protection here if you prefer open access. However, note that without authentication, anyone can reach the interface ‚Äî letting them operate your garage door or upload new firmware.

When you access the WebUI for the first time ‚Äî or from a new device ‚Äî you‚Äôll be redirected to the login page to authenticate. After a successful login, the WebUI stores a secret token to streamline future access. Because this token remains valid indefinitely, be sure to log out manually (via Settings > Logout) when you‚Äôre finished, especially if others share the device.
This page provides a guide on how to update your board using the WebUI When an update is available, you will be notified on your dashboard

When updating the firmware or filesystem, follow this sequence: Update the filesystem first, then update the firmware. If no filesystem update is required, update only the firmware. If you want to downgrade the system to an older version, you need to do this by flashing it manually, because OTA cannot guarante that it will work. You can try it, but it may fail.
Update files are available here. Download the firmware and filesystem (fs) binary files, and upload them according to the update order.
The firmware binary updates the core functionality of the PandaGarage board. This is the code that drives the device's operations.
The filesystem binary contains the WebUI and related files.

If your board is set up, you have two options on how to change the WiFi network: You can enter the new SSID and the password on the settings page and after a restart, it will connect to the new network. If it fails to connect to the new network, it will fallback to hotspot mode. You can directly restart to the hotspot mode, where you can change the WiFi settings.
Currently the following languages are supported: üá¨üáß English üá©üá™ German üá´üá∑ French üá™üá∏ Spanish üáÆüáπ Italian üá≥üá± Dutch

If you'd like to add a new translation to the project, please start by copying this file. It‚Äôs a JSON file containing all strings used in the WebUI. Translate each string accordingly, and once completed, name the file using the appropriate language code ‚Äî for example, en for English or de for German. When you're done, open a new issue on GitHub and select New Translation Submission. Fill the required fields and upload your translated file. After a review it will be added.

The process is identical to adding a new translation, except that you modify an existing file instead of creating a new one. Simply update the relevant strings in the corresponding language file and submit your changes the same way as for the new translation.
ESP32 S3 based controller for H√∂rmann Garage Doors.
If you want to go straight to the web installer, just press the button below. Otherwise, follow the getting started guide. Web InstallerGetting Started

PandaGarage is a control board designed for H√∂rmann garage doors, to make them smart. Using this board, you can control your garage door using the WebUI, Home Assistant, HTTP API or MQTT. Additionaly the board comes with three onboard sensor for temperature, humidity and a light sensor. It features I2C header pins for additional sensors. It also includes a buzzer, which enables you to play different melodys while the door opens or closes.

Currently, the board is in its final development phase and is not yet available for purchase. However, a preorder option is planned for the near future. To stay updated, consider joining our Discord community. The entire project is open-source, giving you the freedom to modify it as you like.
documents.s: Where can I get this board?

documents.t: This project is currently sponsored by JLCPCB / EasyEDA, but welcomes additional support from the community. If you're interested in supporting this project, you can: Reach out on Discord here. Contribute to the codebase on GitHub. Your contributions and support are greatly appreciated!
documents.s: How can I support this project?
